awd_titl_txt: 2019 FASEB SRC on RNA localization and local translation
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support US-based graduate student, postdoctoral and early career investigator attendance at the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology (FASEB) meeting at Snowmass, CO on June 30 - July 5, 2019. The meeting focuses on RNA localization and local translation and is co-organized by Ruth Lehmann, Fulvia Bono, Simon Bullock and Antonella Riccio. The format of the meeting is a combination of 28 invited talks, 22 talks selected from submitted abstracts and several poster sessions. Three keynote lectures by leaders in the field of RNA structure and localization will be given throughout the meeting. There is a dedicated 2-hour session for trainees to interact with leading experts at the meeting and two different career-workshops will be held focusing on "Big ideas for the RNA field" and "Entrepreneurial opportunities for RNA biology and therapeutics." This meeting affords many opportunities (both formal and informal) for sharing recent research findings and exploring collaborations. 

This is a unique biannual meeting focusing on RNA localization and regulation that began in 1994. Recent advances on how the spatial and often developmentally-programmed localization of RNA impacts cell development and function will be highlighted in this conference. The session topics include RNA transport, translation control, RNA localization, developmental processes, RNA in disease, RNA processing and RNP structure. The conference primarily highlights unpublished research findings and provides many experiences for young researchers to learn about the field and devise future avenues for research. The meeting will bring together diverse scientists and encourage career development of a new generation of researchers, including those who are underrepresented in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

FINAL REPORT

 

FASEB SCIENCE RESEARCH CONFERENCE:

The RNA Localization and Local Translation Conference

Snowmass, Colorado

30th June – 5th July 2019

 

Conference Organizers:

Dr Simon Bullock, MRC-LMB, Cambridge, UK

Prof. Ruth Lehmann, Skirball Institute, NYU, USA

Prof. Antonella Riccio, MRC-LMCB/University College London, UK

Dr Fulvia Bono, University of Exeter, UK

 

Highlights of sessions and topics discussed:

The FASEB Science Research Conference on RNA Localization and Local Translation was a huge success judging by feedback from delegates at the meeting and the evaluation questionnaire given by. 82 respondents.

Several delegates commented specifically on the time available for discussions and the opportunities to interact with PIs, as these were two of our key objectives when planning the meeting. Judging from the conversations we witnessed it is anticipated that several new collaborations will arise directly from this meeting.

There were 51 oral presentations, of which 26 were from invited speakers. The 25 short talks were predominantly by trainees and junior faculty. Our decision to have invited speakers give talks of 20 minutes plus 10 minutes (as opposed to the more typical “25 plus 5” format) was vindicated by the in-depth question and answer sessions after each talk, which usually included valuable contributions from trainees.  There were 77 posters, with 23 poster presenters (mostly PhD students) having an opportunity to advertise their work in 2-minute poster flash talks. Overall, the quality of the presentations at the meeting was outstanding.

Prof. Tom Cech (Nobel Prize for Chemistry, 1989) set the stage for the conference with his opening keynote lecture. There were two other inspirational keynotes at the meeting, from Profs. Elena Conti and Joan Steitz. Other invited speakers covered a broad range of topics related to the spatial control of RNA biology, including mRNA transport, local translation, RNA surveillance, and RNA biology in neurons, development and disease. The full repertoire of modern methodologies was represented including biochemistry, genetics, structural biology, high throughput ‘omics’, and advanced microscopy. In addition to the invited speakers, a group of senior investigators attended and chaired sessions. 

The meeting had two workshops. The first took place on the first full day and involved delegates being assigned tables at lunch, with each table being asked to discuss two outstanding questions in field (previously submitted for consideration by invited speakers). The tables included a mixture of trainees and PIs. After lunch, trainees from each table presented their table’s conclusions to the rest of the delegates in the seminar room. By encouraging interactions between delegates at different career stages this workshop served as a very successful icebreaker, and also raised scientific questions that would be revisited multiple times during the meeting. The second workshop was a unique chance for delegates to hear from, and ask questions to, attendees with significant experience in commercial biotechnology/pharmaceuticals and/or entrepreneurship. Informal presentations were given by Prof. Cech (long term member of Merck’s advisory board), Dr Zandy Forbes (founder and CEO of Meira GTX) and Prof. Steve McKnight (co-founder of Tularik Pharmaceuticals). This proved to be a fascinating and informative experience for many of delegates who attended, especially for those considering careers in this sector. There were also two well attended ‘Meet-the-speaker’ lunches

 

Overview of the funding outcomes:

We  received $12 000 from NSF and used thees  funds for Early Career Awards to junior delegates.  29 such awards were made of 4x $100, 17 x $400 or 8 x $600. 

 

Overview of the attendees:

134 people (working in 13 different countries) registered for the meeting. Delegates came from as far as Australia and South Africa. Approximately 40% of delegates were based outside the USA. The gender balance was as follows:

Organizers: 3 female, 1 male (75% female)

Invited speakers: 16 female, 10 male (62% female)

Session chairs: 3 female, 4 male (43% female)


 


Last Modified: 10/01/2020
Modified by: Ruth Lehmann
